text: has anyone thought about / tried coating the 3D printed coral with any other materials? I was looking into 3D printed hermit crab shells ( <http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12784/#comments> ) and someone made a really interesting comment about using electrolysis to grow limestone onto a print.  might be interesting to experiment with

attachments.title: Project Shellter - Shell 01 by TeamTeamUSA
attachments.text: UPDATE 2011-10-25I uploaded shell-012948.stl, the file as exported from Sage, for shell thickening experimentation. It was mirrored from the original exported file because a hermit crab needs a right-handed shell spiral due to the way its abdomen curves.Pimp out your hermit crab!This is the prototype shell for Project Shellter, the current artist residency at MakerBot <http://Industries.It|Industries.It> is modeled on the shell of the Cittarium pica sea snail, <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cittarium_pica>, and is similar to the ones that crabs in pet stores typically <http://sport.It|sport.It> was created using Sage, <http://sagemath.org>, exported to an STL using a modified version of Christopher Olah's plugin, <http://trac.sagemath.org/sage_trac/ticket/7744>, and thickened in 3DS Max.You can explore other shell shapes here <http://sagenb.org/home/pub/2928> (account required).The goal is a workflow using open source tools, but the conversion of the surface to a solid at this point requires a commercial tool.Maybe someone can figure out a way to thicken the surface without 3DS Maxâ€½Follow Project Shellter progress here:<http://projectshellter.comhttp://twitter.com/ProjectShellterhttp://bit.ly/ProjectShellterhttp://bit.ly/ProjectShellterCamshttp://bit.ly/ProjectShellterVideos>

text: Autodesk guy we were with can connect us to the head of their bio/tissue engineering group.
